message.content:
cs.CC, cs.DS, cs.AI, cs.CG, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with complexity theory and approximation algorithms, which are typically covered in the cs.CC (Computational Complexity) and cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) sub-categories. The use of Probabilistically Checkable Proofs (PCPs) and randomness-efficient soundness- and hardness-amplification techniques suggest a focus on theoretical computer science, which could also place the paper in the cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) or cs.CG (Computational Geometry) sub-categories. Finally, the mention of optimization problems and attempts to derandomize the AM complexity class suggest a connection to machine learning and optimization, which could place the paper in the cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-category.
